data.title: SBAllen, GameFAQs Administrator, is stepping down from the site, and parting ways with Fandom. News
data.meta_description:
https://gamefaqs.gamespot.com/boards/6-gamefaqs-announcements/80595955

This was announced on GameFAQs board. Close if old.
data.text:
delete12345

One Winged Slayer

Nov 17, 2017

20,418

Boston, MA

Oct 18, 2023

#1

SBAllen said:

Howdy all. Just a quick message to let everyone know that I'll be stepping down as an Admin for GameFAQs as I've decided to part ways with Fandom.

I've enjoyed my time working on this site and I'll stick around as a Moderator for now and to offer whatever knowledge I can to those still working on the site, but after 20 long years I just don't enjoy things like I used to and need to find some new challenge to tackle.

Thanks everyone, I'll still be around, possibly more as I move back down to a user rather than an Admin. Looking forward to seeing where things go for the site in the future.

Stepping down as admin - GameFAQs Announcements Message Board - GameFAQs

On GameFAQs Announcements, a GameFAQs message board topic titled "Stepping down as admin".

This was announced on GameFAQs board. Close if old.

#18

When Romancing SaGa 2 was released on Vita in 2017, it was translated and localized "out of nowhere" and the only resources for it were decades old fan works from the earliest days of the internet. The game is famously esoteric with tons of hidden mechanics, pathways, characters, and plot progressions and to experience the game to its fullest really required help and support from people who already knew the game and had unlocked its obtuse secrets. It would not have been possible for me to complete it without referencing an robust, albeit incomplete, GameFAQs text-only walkthrough from 1999.

This is the sort of precious historic material that is at risk, so I hope there is an effort right now to scrape and extract all this content that might be delisted or deleted because they aren't revenue drivers for a new owner.

Wait, doesn't Fandom own Gamefaqs? How did this guy own it?

Didn't CJayC found it?

Correct, Jeff Veasey or CJayC founded the site back in 1996, and stepped down around 2007 and left the forums. SBAllen has been in charge since then. SBAllen was already a prominent guide author back then too, under the alias of Sailor Bacon.

My username has survived 23 years and several forum transitions. Hell I think if you were to google search it, every single reference to "OmegaDL50" online will lead back to me.

It's obviously fantastic that it's all archived but I feel the visibilty and (in)famousness of GameFAQs has helped retro game culture thrive to the point that it's at now. Younger people keep going back to retro games and love them and I think there's an understanding that many of them are enhanced by guides, and some games more or less require them.

I hope there will be some user-friendly hub for people to access the guides. They won't help people being stuck on one archive.org page. Legally that's a minefield but that's what needs to happen once GameFAQs is fully Fandom'd. It needs the visibility

So SBAllen retired before I hit 10k karma (just like a year to go!), dang

I haven't used the forums… or site in general, in years, but I do keep an active login to keep gaining those karma points!

I did this too for awhile, figured I would eventually get the "? Block" status after a few more years of regular visits, but after seeing too many awful posters with massive karma counts I figured, what's the point? One literally had a maga signature.

Wish I didn't spend so much time on the forums; it was miserable. Trolls and assholes would stick around forever. The limit on posters you could ignore was laughably low and I eventually ran out of dormant accounts to prune. Sometimes I'll check the forums for new games and recognize the same assholes from a decade ago or more, still posting in the exact same ways.

It sounds like the actual stuff of value from the site has been preserved. The forums could and probably should go away and the internet would be better for it.

Yeah, I'm using a GameFAQs guide right now as I play through GrimGrimoire. I vastly prefer written guides… just not the modern SEO-poisoned kind you see everywhere else.

When Romancing SaGa 2 was released on Vita in 2017, it was translated and localized "out of nowhere" and the only resources for it were decades old fan works from the earliest days of the internet. The game is famously esoteric with tons of hidden mechanics, pathways, characters, and plot progressions and to experience the game to its fullest really required help and support from people who already knew the game and had unlocked its obtuse secrets. It would not have been possible for me to complete it without referencing an robust, albeit incomplete, GameFAQs text-only walkthrough from 1999.

This is the sort of precious historic material that is at risk, so I hope there is an effort right now to scrape and extract all this content that might be delisted or deleted because they aren't revenue drivers for a new owner.

Indeed.

Gamefaqs also hosts what is considered THE reference/walkthrough in English for anyone delving into works like Unlimited SaGa (a game notorious for not explaining any of its mechanics to the player).

There have been many, many amazing guides created there long before the days of video walkthroughs and wiki pages/sites, and the individual game forums made it easier for people to have discussions/questions about any particular game.
